headline.main: What's in the House's Medicare Bill

docs.lead_paragraph: Under the gaze of a replica of a dinosaur skull, Speaker Newt Gingrich opened a very modern marketplace in his office today, trading small favors for big votes needed to pass a Medicare bill. One after another, dozens of lawmakers trooped in seeking concessions, and Mr. Gingrich tried to please them without significantly altering the Republican proposal to slow the growth of Medicare.

headline.main: Gingrich Busily Trades Favors for Medicare Votes

docs.lead_paragraph: The Acting Insurance Commissioner, Elizabeth Randall, yesterday postponed implementation of a state policy that would allow insurance companies to use blood tests for H.I.V. and deny coverage for those who are infected, the A.P. reported. The policy is in the regulatory review process, which means there is time for individuals and groups to submit written comments about the policy to the State Department of Insurance. Commissioner Randall extended the public comment period by 30 days, to Nov. 30.

docs.lead_paragraph: Being slightly overweight poses little risk for men and women over 70, a study has found, but being thinner than normal can be dangerous. Using a formula based on height and weight, researchers found the risk of mortality to be high in elderly people who are underweight, rising sharply the leaner they were.

headline.main: For Elderly, Thinner Isn't Better, Researchers Say

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: "Bribes for the Doctors" (editorial, Oct. 15) is an inflammatory headline. That "a softening of proposed pay cuts" in Medicare for doctors can be held up as a symbol of avariciousness by physicians suggests that Orwellian newspeak is alive and well at The New York Times.

docs.lead_paragraph: Senate Republicans moved yesterday to cut in half the $30 billion that large companies would be expected to take back from their workers' pension plans under a bill passed earlier by the House. Secretary of Labor Robert B. Reich criticized the Senate plan, contending that it was "only a slight narrowing" of a "bad policy" that would cause seemingly sound pension plans to fail. The plan, put forth by Republicans on the Finance Committee, would limit the use of withdrawn funds to paying for other benefits for workers and retirees, including health insurance, disability benefits, child care and educational assistance. The Senate version would raise $4.9 billion in taxes over seven years, indicating that almost $15 billion would be withdrawn from pension plans, half the $30 billion estimated by the House, which placed no restrictions on the use of funds withdrawn.

docs.lead_paragraph: AT the age of 70, and still making scientific discoveries, Dr. Oliver Smithies of the University of North Carolina in Chapel Hill, has had a long career studded with startling results. But one moment stands out: a sudden insight into the glories and uncertainties of research that perfectly describes why he so loves to do experiments. It was the morning of May 18, 1985, three years and one month after Dr. Smithies had begun his quest to insert genes into specified positions in cellular DNA. If he succeeded in this "gene targeting," it would be a remarkable achievement, making possible the creation of diseases like cystic fibrosis and atherosclerosis in laboratory animals, allowing scientists to test drugs and prevention strategies and to understand the genetic basis of disease. But it was risky and uncertain. In fact, at one point Dr. Smithies's students gave up on the project, saying they were going on to other things.

headline.main: SCIENTIST AT WORK: Oliver Smithies;Sprinting Along for Five Decades
